bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Domingo F. Ramos, November 22, 1944

div1.p: Kean discusses Finlay's mosquito theory and Reed's research.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Domingo F. Ramos, November 22, 1944
div1.opener:
2 copies
Copy of letter to Dr Domingo F. Ramos
2804 N STREET. N. W.
WASHINGTON 7. D. C.
Nov. 22, 1944
Instituto Finlay
Habana Cuba
My dear Dr Ramos
div1.p:
The letter of Dr Albertini to Gen. A. E. Truby
which came in my care was forwarded to
him unopened as I did not know that it
contained a letter from you to me. He has
just sent your letter and Dr. Albertini's to me-
Gen Truby who has had the misfortune of a cerebral
hemorrhage, has requested me to give my opinion
of what should be done about Dr. Albertinis letter
He has, as I have also, an earnest desire to meet
Dr A's wishes- But it is rather difficult to
find out at what particular date that distin-
guished Board of Expert Diagnosticians became
convinced of the truth of the Finlay Theory of
transmission of Yellow Fever- Was it before Oct. 10
the date of Reeds letter, or after they had seen
2
the case of Kissinger and the subsequent
experimental cases? This is the question raised
by Dr. Albertini and it is a difficult
one to decide after forty four years-
He can speak for himself and no one would
think of questioning it- But can he speak
for Gorgas and Juan Guiteras? We all
know that Gorgas had not accepted it
even four months lated when Reed reported
his 11 conclusions to the Pan American Medical
Congress in February 1901. He has with perfect
frankness put this on record in his last
report to Gen. Wood and he told me so
just before the time of the Congress- With regard to
Dr Guiteras, for whose memory I have a
very affectionate regard. I do not know-
we know that he promptly accepted the evidence
of Reeds carefully controlled experiments and
3
was convinced before the famous dinner
which the doctors of Havana gave to Dr
Finlay to celebrate the confirmation of his theory
This was on Dec. 22 1900 and Dr Guiteras
made the introductory speech which I remem-
ber well as I had the honor of sitting next
to that dear old man the guest of honor-
I will see if I can find any thing which
would shed light on the date of his conversion
as it is the only date in question- In the
interest of historical truth it should not
be assumed that he had made up his mind
before he saw the first experimental case.
I do not think that it would add to his
reputation to have done so- I had a visit
from Dr Hench some after you did me the
honor to call on Nov. 1st and he told me
of the happy chance by which he found you
4
in New York- His opinion will probably
be desired by Gen Truby as to what may
be the best thing to do to meet Dr Albertini's
wishes-
div1.closer:
With cordial regards J R K
Postscript- Gen Truby makes a note on the
margin of Dr. A's letter that the expression
to which he takes exception occurs in a letter
to him and not to Reed's wife as stated by
Dr A- The page reference also is not accurate.
So the letter would have to be rewritten
after all the evidence is in- It will not be
easy to prove what individuals thought of
the Finlay Theory before the demonstration by
Reeds experiments was placed before them
and when Reed permed this hasty note
to Truby they had not seen the first case
Kissinger, which they saw later that day-
We all know that Dr Finlay had made very
5
Nov 22, 1944
few converts in Havana before the Camp
Lazear demonstration and I do not see
why it should be considered a reflection
on any member of the Yellow Fever Board
to be skeptical on Oct. 10- After Reed's
paper was read on Feb 4, 1901 it was differ-
ent. It is very fortunate that you as
the Director of the Institue Finlay are inter-
ested in this question and I think that
it might be well to have the decision as
to what action should be taken, if any,
left to you and Colonel Hench to determine
you are more disinterested parties than
Gen. Truby and I about any criticism
of Major Walter Reed-
Yours Sincerely
J. R. K.
